ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It's best to think about this course as half history course, half about the actual lived realities of diplomacy and negotiation. I learned a ton. A lot of Jackson classes use a memo style or focus on practice, but Professor Rank's is the only one that I'm leaving feeling truly confident that I will use the specific skills he taught us.
Great introduction to the Korean Peninsula crisis
I gained skills on memo writing and how to be more concise and to the point in my writing. As well as how to think quickly on my feet and how diplomacy really takes place.

I learned so much about the work of a diplomat, concrete knowledge about the history of the Korean peninsula + all four parties we studied, how to write a memo, how to field questions in a murder board, and so much more.
Learned how to write policy memos in concise, succinct sentences.

I learned not just the history of Korea and great power relationships on the peninsula, but also how to be an effective diplomat.  I gained insight on how to write memos in the State Department style, as well as other diplomatic techniques used at the negotiating table and within the agency.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I love prof. rank, easily one of my favorite course at yale

Strengths: Prof. Rank is super engaged and a wonderful teacher. The exercises are fun and well-facilitated towards learning. The small class size is also great for engagement and getting to know the Professor and classmates better.

Weakness: None particularly to note, expect maybe more advice on the structures of memos.

Prof Rank is by far the course's biggest strength! He is so knowledgeable, funny, and great at explaining very complex situations and issues in an easily digestible way. The readings are also interesting, and the group activities (such as the six-party talks simulation) were fun and let us apply what we learned in a hands-on, creative way.

The lectures were divided half into historical review and diplomatic skills, with discussion and reading review in between, so every class had a healthy variety.  Guest lectures added real-world context to the reading material.  It was really well organized and a fairly holistic review of modern Korean geopolitics.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: very engaging class, debates and discussions helped
The class was well-adapted to Zoom -- the virtual guests were super interesting!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Best course at Yale, highly recommend

This is a really great course. Prof. Rank is a boss who really cares about his students and gives clear feedback and creates fun exercises. It's a great class for those wanting to know the real way  diplomacy is conducted.
Yes! If you're interested at all in the Korean peninsula, take this class! You will be surprised and delighted with how much you learn.
Definitely, if you're interested in Korean affairs or just have a broad interest in East Asia, regardless of major.

Yes.  Even if you are not that interested in East Asia, the practical diplomatic skills alone make this class worth it.  Additionally, misconceptions about the relationships between the two Koreas, China, and the United States are examined, giving an understanding of peninsular affairs more closely grounded in reality.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments:
In-class discussion, debate, presentations
Writing memos
